abstracts.cdata!:
This is the Implementation Completion
            Report (ICR) for the Multiproject in Western Samoa. The
            project consisted of a group of high-priority subprojects in
            the agriculture, industry and infrastructure sectors. These
            subprojects complemented each other, and/or supported
            specific production activities, with a view to strengthening
            and diversifying of the economic base, enhancing generation
            of new economic activities, and creating new employment
            opportunities. The subprojects were accorded a high priority
            by the Government in its fifth development plan (1985-87)
            and were supported by ADB  and UNDP, they were of a
            complementary nature and supported productive activities,
            and they had estimated acceptable economic rates of returns,
            especially in the cases of the agricultural and road
            development subprojects. Although these subprojects had been
            evaluated to determine their suitability for ADB/IDA
            financing, detailed economic analysis of the individual
            subprojects was to be undertaken by the Govemment, with the
            assistance of consultants, and were only toproceed if
            approved by ADB/IDA and if they met a cutoff point of a 12
            percent economic rate of return, and/or recovered costs.
            Subprojects could be added to or substituted forthe four
            tentative subprojects which were: (i) tree crop development;
            (ii) rural roadupgrading; (iii) construction of a small
            industries center; and (iv) upgrading of Apiaharbor's
            container park. A key lesson is that the experience of this
            particular projectcarnnot be taken, on its own, as
            demonstrating the Multiproject approach as a costeffective
            method of delivering assistance to small countries. The tree
            crop andpower subprojects required different supervision
            skills, which were forthcoming, but at acost. This
            particular project appears to have struck a reasonable
            balance between meetingthe available small investment
            opportunities - which may range across sectors - and
            costeffectivenessof supervision. The experience of the
            project should be taken as indicatingthat great caution is
            needed towards the Multiproject approach, and the need for
            aconcerted effort during preparation to consider component
            design and a detailed, costed,supervision plan. It
            reconfirms the importance of making an upfront judgrnent as
            towhether the quantity, quality, and skills mix of
            supervision resources which canrealistically be budgeted, is
            in line with the needs for successful implementation.
